title: The Different Stages of Sannyasa | HH Stoka Krishna Swami
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: There are four stages of advancement in sannyas.
segments.summary: The lecture introduces the four stages of sannyasa: Kutichaka, Bahudaka, Parivrajaka, and Paramahamsa.
segments.transcript: There are four stages of advancement in sannyas: Kutichaka, Bahudaka, Parivrajaka, Paramahamsa.

segments.key_quote: They can fully devote themselves for practicing tapasya, for studying the scriptures, for practicing austerity, etc.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the Kutichaka stage of sannyasa, where individuals live in a simple cottage and focus on spiritual practices.
segments.transcript: Kutichaka is the beginning stage of sannyas. Prabhupada says generally they construct a cottage outside the village or outside the usual place of residence, and they live there. And from home, they receive some simple food so that they are not bothered about preparing food, gathering the ingredients, etc. They can fully devote themselves for practicing tapasya, for studying the scriptures, for practicing austerity, etc.

segments.key_quote: Madhukari means the business of a bumble bee.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the Bahudaka stage, also known as Madhukari, comparing it to a bumble bee collecting nectar from many flowers.
segments.transcript: Bahudaka means he will collect a little, little, little from many homes by going and begging, bhiksha. And this is also called Madhukari. Madhukari means the business of a bumble bee. A bee collects the nectar from flowers, a very little from each flower, but it gathers so much that it is able to make a whole honeycomb.

segments.key_quote: Parivrajaka does not stay in one place.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the Parivrajaka stage, where sannyasis travel and preach, adhering to strict rules of not staying in one place for more than three days.
segments.transcript: When one becomes even further advanced, then one starts travelling. Then one starts learning and preaching. Parivrajaka does not stay in one place. According to the strict rules of sannyas ashram, one should not stay in a place more than three days.

segments.key_quote: Devotees who are fully devoted to serving Krishna without caring for any personal comforts, they are actually, paramahamsas
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the Paramahamsa stage, emphasizing pure devotion to Krishna and explaining how the essence of sannyasa is adapted for preaching in Kali Yuga.
segments.transcript: As the Paramahamsa is above all varnas and all ashramas, he's a pure devotee. Devotees who are fully devoted to serving Krishna without caring for any personal comforts, they are actually paramahamsas. So these strict rules of sannyas are not possible to be followed in Kali Yuga. Therefore, in Kali Yuga it is said sannyas is forbidden, but even the followers of Chaitanya, they accept the essence of this principle of sannyas, which is traveling and preaching, and some minimum rules of sannyas are accepted, but not all the rules, so that the preaching can be done without much difficulty, and that's our main business.
